desktop-commander.description: Provides filesystem access, terminal execution, long-running interactive TUI process control, and diff-based file editing from an MCP client.
useCases: Running a long-lived terminal task and interacting with it incrementally (e.g., a server log monitor, htop, ncurses apps).
Editing files safely using diff-based patches rather than rewriting full files.
Managing running processes: listing processes, streaming output, sending signals.
notGoodFor: Web automation or browser control (use Playwright instead).
High-volume structured data processing (use native APIs or script pipelines).
Use in unsecured environments without sandboxing (requires containerization for safe deployment).
limitations: Interactive TUI behavior depends on terminal/PTY environment and may be fragile in misconfigured shells.
Grants high system access — should be sandboxed or isolated.
Long-running sessions require stable process supervision to avoid orphan processes.
desktop-commander.examplePrompt: Start a persistent htop session and stream process list output to help monitor system load trends over the next 5 minutes.

playwright.description: Browser automation via Playwright exposed through MCP. Allows navigation, DOM interactions, screenshots, form submission, and structured extraction.
useCases: Automated testing of web UIs and flows.
Extracting structured content when no API is available.
Filling forms or simulating user interactions deterministically.
notGoodFor: Attempting to control native applications (use desktop-commander for that).
High-speed scraping of large datasets (browser automation is slower than HTTP-based extraction).
Sites requiring CAPTCHA or strong bot detection handling without proxies.
limitations: Browser context reinitialization may reset session/state.
Running multiple concurrent browser contexts increases memory and CPU usage.
Detected by some anti-bot mechanisms without additional configuration.
playwright.examplePrompt: Navigate to https://news.ycombinator.com and return the titles and URLs of the top 10 stories.

zai-mcp-server.description: Provides Z AI model access via MCP for text analysis, classification, summarization, or conversation tasks.
useCases: Summarizing large bodies of text.
Generating or rewriting content.
Semantic classification or topic extraction.
notGoodFor: System-level automation or file operations.
Browser or desktop control (pair with Playwright or desktop-commander instead).
Tasks requiring deterministic rule-based output (LLMs are probabilistic).
limitations: Quality and behavior depend on the underlying model.
Output can drift or require prompting technique tuning.
zai-mcp-server.examplePrompt: Summarize the following Slack conversation into a concise status update with next steps.

sequential-thinking.description: A reasoning scaffolding MCP server that structures task execution into deliberate multi-step sequences.
useCases: Breaking ambiguous tasks into smaller sequential steps.
Planning multi-phase workflows before executing.
Enforcing slower, more deliberate reasoning to reduce mistakes.
notGoodFor: Tasks requiring immediate execution rather than planning.
Low-latency or real-time operations.
Automations where each step is already well-defined.
limitations: Adds overhead and latency to responses.
Does not execute tasks itself — requires pairing with another MCP server.
Structured plans may still require validation or human review.
sequential-thinking.examplePrompt: Plan the steps required to migrate a legacy database to PostgreSQL before executing any commands.

chrome-devtools.description: Direct Chrome DevTools Protocol access for browser automation, performance analysis, and debugging with native Chrome integration.
useCases: Performance profiling and analysis of web applications.
Native Chrome DevTools automation for debugging workflows.
Browser automation when Chrome-specific features are required.
Network request inspection and console message analysis.
notGoodFor: Cross-browser testing (use Playwright for multi-browser support).
Production web scraping without proper anti-detection measures.
File system operations or system-level automation (use desktop-commander).
Applications requiring extensive form automation without debugging focus.
limitations: Limited to Chrome/Chromium browsers only.
Several active bugs including screenshot resets in mobile emulation.
No built-in cookie management or user agent modification.
Browser instance cleanup issues - no clean shutdown mechanism.
Protocol connection errors under certain conditions.
chrome-devtools.examplePrompt: Analyze the performance metrics of https://example.com and identify the top 3 performance bottlenecks affecting page load time.

serena.description: Advanced coding agent toolkit providing semantic retrieval and editing capabilities through symbol-level operations. Acts like an IDE with refactoring, code navigation, and multi-language support.
useCases: Large codebase analysis and understanding
Safe refactoring across multiple files
Finding references and symbol relationships
Working with polyglot/monorepo projects
IDE-like code navigation and editing
notGoodFor: Simple text editing tasks
Projects without proper language server support
Very small codebases where overhead isn't justified
Environments with strict security requirements
limitations: Requires Python 3.11+ and proper language server setup
Can be resource-intensive on large projects
May experience timeouts with very large codebases
Some tools execute code without permission prompts
serena.examplePrompt: Analyze this codebase to understand the architecture, then refactor the UserService class to follow the repository pattern, updating all references across the project.

context7.description: Real-time documentation search and retrieval MCP server providing up-to-date code documentation for 50,000+ libraries. Injects current documentation context directly into AI development workflows.
useCases: Finding the latest documentation for any library or framework during development
Getting context about unfamiliar APIs before writing code
Verifying function signatures and parameters in real-time
Cross-referencing documentation across multiple libraries
Staying updated with breaking changes and version-specific documentation
Building prompts with accurate, up-to-date library information
notGoodFor: Low-latency operations requiring immediate responses (documentation lookup adds overhead)
Offline development scenarios without internet connectivity
Very stable legacy codebases where documentation rarely changes
Tasks not involving external library reference or documentation
limitations: Requires internet connectivity to fetch documentation
Rate limiting applies without API key - higher limits with free account from context7.com/dashboard
API key required for production usage or higher rate limits
Documentation freshness depends on source repositories and indexing
Some niche libraries may not be available in the database
context7.examplePrompt: Show me the latest documentation for React hooks and fetch the current API reference for the OpenAI v1 API to help write a new integration.
